stream_context.summary: Kaze continues work on the Cowboy level’s Mole Hideout encounter: tuning Monty Mole rock-throw physics, making spawns random across holes, and iterating on a simple “defeat the moles” boss concept. Mid-stream he reveals a major engine change: replacing SM64’s collision with a new custom collision system for stability (with side effects like BLJ being harder/less common). He also discusses design philosophy (how he interprets player criticism), gives a concrete remaining-scope estimate (~80% complete), and briefly talks business plans post-release (Kickstarter for an original 3D platformer and hiring ROM hackers).
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a major technical pivot—Kaze says he replaced Mario 64’s collision system entirely—plus the Cowboy level’s star objectives are nearing “done” (stars 1–2) and he states a clear overall completion estimate and remaining level count, which meaningfully anchors the project timeline.

findings.summary: Kaze says he replaced SM64’s original collision with a completely new custom collision system because the original was “unusable,” and demonstrates improved stability (less sticking in messy geometry).
He notes the new, more stable physics/collision has an unintended gameplay side effect: BLJ becomes harder/less available, which he considers a negative side effect he’d like to avoid if possible.
Kaze articulates a bug/tech-debt policy: keep “bugs” that require intentional player action (like BLJ-style exploits), but remove issues that can happen accidentally during normal play.

He implements/tunes Monty Mole rock throws by computing a per-frame-step sum (discrete-time gravity) to derive an initial Y-velocity so rocks land correctly at Mario’s position, then confirms it works in-game.
He explicitly chooses non-predictive aiming for thrown rocks (shoot at Mario’s current position, not leading his velocity), focusing on fairness/feel rather than anti-speedrun countermeasures.
He discovers and fixes aiming/spawn issues (e.g., flipped values causing wrong behavior, offset shots), then adds randomized hole selection so moles can’t be picked off one-by-one.

Boss encounter direction shifts from a ‘formal boss’ to a simpler arena-clear concept: defeat multiple moles emerging from different holes, with randomness to keep it engaging without overcomplicating readability.
He temporarily removes collision on a Cowboy level bridge due to RAM constraints, indicating current memory budgeting is still affecting geometry/collision decisions.
While wiring death/loot feedback, he hits SM64 engine safeguards: coin spawning requires setting an amount first due to built-in safety precautions around respawning actors.

Kaze explains how he processes criticism: he tries to identify the underlying feeling a player had rather than implementing the critique literally, because ‘media-literate’ critics can overfit to arbitrary parameters.

He gives a concrete progress snapshot: after this area, he estimates the project is ~80% complete, with three main courses, two side levels, and one Bowser level remaining; Cowboy stars 1–2 are close to done and star 3 will be the “Goomba imposter tower.”

Post-release plan: alongside Return to Yoshi’s Island’s release, he’s considering launching a Kickstarter for an original 3D platformer and transitioning to that, potentially hiring other ROM hackers to help.

Chat pitches multiple boss-fight variations (e.g., hammer, survival waves, star gimmicks, bomb-based solution); Kaze rejects several for theme/readability and lands on a random-hole multi-mole concept.

memorable_quotes.context: Major technical reveal framing why he rewrote a core engine subsystem and what problem it solved (stability/stuck issues).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: When I receive a criticism, I try to figure out what the person was feeling that's wrong… I try to address their feeling instead of their actual critique.
memorable_quotes.context: Concise statement of his feedback philosophy, useful as documentary narration about iterative design and playtesting interpretation.

key_stories.title: Replacing Mario 64’s collision with a custom system
key_stories.summary: Kaze reveals he rewrote collision because the original SM64 collision became a blocker for stability and level geometry complexity. He demonstrates improved behavior in previously ‘stuck-prone’ areas, but notes it changes emergent tech like BLJ.
key_stories.challenge: SM64’s collision was producing unstable behavior (getting stuck in awkward geometry) and was ‘unusable’ for his needs.
key_stories.process: He implemented a new collision system and tested it live in troublesome geometry spots to verify stability.
key_stories.outcome: Movement/collision becomes much more stable, but BLJ becomes harder/less common—an unintended consequence he views as a drawback.
key_stories.key_quote: I made a completely new collision system. I said, fuck Mario 64's collision. It is unusable.

key_stories.title: Making the Mole Hideout rock-throw fight work (discrete physics + fairness)
key_stories.summary: The stream’s core dev work is getting Monty Moles to emerge from holes and throw rocks that reliably reach Mario. Kaze struggles with deriving the correct initial Y-velocity, then switches to discrete per-frame math and iteration until the throw feels right.
key_stories.challenge: Rocks weren’t traveling correctly (wrong distance/offset), especially with vertical differences; the behavior needed consistent results without predictive aiming.
key_stories.process: He derives the motion using a sum of per-frame gravity steps, fixes flipped parameters/offset logic, and explicitly chooses non-predictive targeting (shoot at current Mario position).
key_stories.outcome: Rock throws become reliable enough to proceed; he begins tuning damage/coin drops and behavior edge cases (dying, intangible state).
key_stories.key_quote: We computed the proper sum of frame steps and then made it go towards Mario.

key_stories.title: Boss design pivots toward ‘simple and readable’
key_stories.summary: Kaze questions whether a five-mole ‘boss’ is inherently fun or just noisy/visually cluttered. He considers dropping the boss entirely (just a star) or implementing a minimal multi-enemy clear, ultimately favoring randomized holes to prevent trivializing the encounter.
key_stories.challenge: A multi-mole boss risks being lame, cluttered, or hard to read (too many rocks, unclear interactions, easy to pick off enemies).
key_stories.process: He brainstorms live, evaluates chat ideas against theme (western/cowboy) and clarity, and selects a straightforward ‘defeat the moles’ structure with randomized hole emergence.
key_stories.outcome: A direction is chosen that matches the level’s mechanic tutorial role and keeps the encounter from becoming overly complex.
key_stories.key_quote: I think we may need a better idea for the boss fight… I kind of made this area before even thinking about it.

key_stories.title: Anchoring the project timeline: “~80% done” and what’s left
key_stories.summary: Kaze states a concrete remaining scope: several main courses, side levels, and a Bowser level still to build, while Cowboy stars 1–2 are close to complete. This gives the documentary a rare quantitative ‘where are we now’ milestone in development.
key_stories.challenge: Without explicit accounting, long ROM-hack projects can feel endless and hard to narrativize.
key_stories.process: He enumerates remaining level counts and immediately identifies the next star focus (Goomba imposter tower).
key_stories.outcome: A clear progress marker emerges for timeline and interview framing; near-term roadmap becomes specific (finish decorations, then star 3).
key_stories.key_quote: The levels left to make after this: three more main courses and two side levels and one Bowser level—we're like 80% of the way there.

open_questions.context: Kaze says he replaced SM64 collision entirely for stability, but it changes emergent movement tech like BLJ and may still have ceiling edge cases.
questions: What specifically made SM64’s collision ‘unusable’ for Return to Yoshi’s Island—was it precision, sticking, performance, authoring complexity, or all of the above?
When you rewrote collision, what were the non-negotiable design goals (e.g., no sticking, deterministic results, slope/ceiling rules), and what tradeoffs did you accept?
How do you decide whether to re-enable BLJ-like behavior intentionally versus treating its disappearance as a ‘fixed bug’ from better physics?

open_questions.context: He debates whether to include a boss at all, then settles on a simple multi-mole fight with random holes and non-predictive aiming.
questions: What feeling do you want the Mole Hideout to leave the player with—comedy, tension, mastery of a new mechanic, or just pacing between platforming beats?
You rejected predictive aiming—what playtest moments made you confident that ‘shoot where Mario is’ is the right kind of fairness for this game?
How did you evaluate the ‘too many rocks / can’t read the fight’ risk, and what rules (caps, spawn timing, arena layout) will you use to keep it readable?

open_questions.context: He removed collision on a bridge ‘for RAM reasons,’ implying active memory budgeting still constrains geometry/collision decisions.
questions: What’s the current RAM/memory budget bottleneck in RTYI—collision triangles, object counts, animation data, or something else?
How often do you have to compromise level design (like removing bridge collision) due to memory, and what’s your plan for getting those features back before release?

open_questions.topic: Post-release Kickstarter and hiring ROM hackers
open_questions.context: Kaze says he may launch a Kickstarter for an original platformer around RTYI’s release and potentially hire ROM hackers to help.
questions: What made you decide the timing—Kickstarter ‘alongside release’—instead of after a cooldown period, and what risks are you trying to manage?
What parts of your workflow would you want other ROM hackers to take over (tools, collision/engine, level scripting, optimization), and how would you coordinate quality/vision?
How has working in UE5 alongside ROM hacking influenced what you want your original platformer to be (tech, art style, design philosophy)?
